title: Can I get accepted into an Ivy League school? - Quora

response.answer_text: I was accepted to four Ivy League institutions and Stanford. I’ll say this: Nobody in my family went to college. Not a single person. In fact, I didn’t even know where Harvard was located – let alone how to apply. So, to put it simply: Yes, I think you can get into an Ivy League School. I think anyone can. Here’s a personal example to get you started: My first day of high school, I walked into my Spanish class. Sit in the front row? HA. I’ll take the dark shadows in the back, thank you very much.  Right after me, another kid walked into the room – he sat front and center. He pulled out a planner and started taking notes. Notes?? What is good with this kid? It’s the first 15 seconds of class. Alright, overachiever marked – plain and simple. As fate would have it, I see him again toward the end of the day waiting on his ride home. I decide to talk to him – at the very least figure out what was in the freaking planner that was so important.  Turns out, he is one of the friendliest people I have ever met. He was two years ahead of me, but he had one simple goal in mind: getting into a top school. Oh, and he was copying the homework on the board into his planner. I didn’t even realize we had an assignment. BOOM. I’m sold. I don’t know who this kid is, but I can smell success brewing. Over the next year, I asked him a million questions and learned from his mistakes. He is now one of my closest friends. He now attends Princeton University.  Here’s my advice: For starters, find people who are also trying to get in, who have applied in the past, or who have experience dealing with these top colleges. Learn from them! Now, I am not saying that just finding smart people will also make you smart. But my mom always said: “Birds of a feather, flock together”. The quote is simple – successful people fly around with successful people. So, if you really want to attend an Ivy League school, and I believe you can, find some people that are going to raise the bar for you. And who knows, maybe you’ll be sitting front and center in Harvard Hall. Photo Credit: MarketWatch, Princeton, Petersons

Getting into an Ivy League college is no small feat it is a long and arduous process. However if your going for it you must back yourself! You can get into Ivy league schools. TL:DR at the bottom! There are four key steps factors/steps you have to take and account for going forward. The first step is apply early! Overall Acceptance Rates 2017: Brown: 9.2% Columbia: 6.9% Cornell: 15.2% Dartmouth: 10.0% Harvard: 5.8% Penn: 12.1% Princeton: 7.3% Stanford: 4.65% (not technically an Ivy, I know) Yale: 6.7% According to these numbers, Cornell, Dartmouth and Penn are by far the easiest Ivy Leagues to get into. But what happens when you take a look at the early decision/early action (ED/EA) acceptance rates? ED/EA Rates 2017: Brown: 18.5% ED Columbia: 19.2% ED Cornell: 29.5% ED Dartmouth: 29.4% ED Harvard: 18.4% EA Penn: 24.9% ED Princeton: 18.3% EA Stanford: 9.5% (2016) EA Yale: 14.4% EA All of a sudden these schools look a lot more attainable although these stats are often skewed due to recruited athletes), showing interest in specific universities early on will definitely help you. Step two is to STUDY! Average Ivy League GPA/Test Scores: Brown: 4.08/ SAT: 1500, ACT: 32 Columbia: 4.16/ SAT: 1530, ACT: 34 Cornell: 4.04/ SAT: 1480, ACT: 32 Dartmouth: 4.06/ SAT: 1500, ACT: 32 Harvard: 4.1/ SAT: 1540, ACT: 34 Penn: 3.93/ SAT: 1510, ACT: 32 Princeton: 3.9/ SAT: 1520, ACT: 33 Stanford: 4.18/ SAT: 1520, ACT: 33 Yale: 4.19/ SAT: 1540, ACT: 33 Don’t be disheartened by these numbers. They are averages, which means that universities take students with lower scores and students with higher scores. If your grades aren’t strong, challenge yourself in school and strengthen other parts of your application. Go out on a limb and show these universities that you are not afraid of failing. Step three is finding your passion! As I mentioned above, the worse your grades are, the better you have to be in non-academic pursuits. So find a passion outside of the classroom and become obsessed with it. Literally. Ivy League universities want to produce world leaders, thinkers and doers, and the only way they can do that is by accepting students who have great potential. Therefore, you have to live and breathe your passion, especially if the rest of your application isn’t up to par. Do you love science? Enrol in international competitions, shadow a doctor, work in a lab, teach elementary school kids the basics of chemistry around the USA in the summer. Do as much as you can as often as you can and prove to the admissions officers why are going to be the best scientist ever. Lastly, be you! show the college what they are missing out on with your own unique perspective of the world. A brilliant example of this would be the essay about pizza that helped a girl receive a offer from Yale. 1. Find a creative point of view and run with it. 2. Be authentic (don’t try to be funny if you are not funny!). 3. Be emotive with your writing. The more you make the admissions officers feel something, the better. 4. Give the admissions officers a reason to fight for you. The more you open up, the better your essay will be, but this doesn't mean you have to write a sob story. Contrary to popular belief, writing about the worst thing that has ever happened in your life will not guarantee you a spot at an Ivy League, or any other university for that matter. As long as you write with passion (and correct spelling and grammar), your essay will be great. Don’t be afraid to take risks! They will most likely pay off. TLDR: 1) Apply Early 2) Study 3)Find your passion and show it through your extracurricular 4)Display your unique perspective on the world through your application Good luck, just remember these schools are very selective and there is no shame in not getting in.

Hi, a recent admit into two of the HYP here (didn't apply to the other one). Asian female (international student).  A few things:1. You are arguably more impressive than I am - so my answer is 'probably'. That's a 'probably' because NO ONE should be able to say with 100% confidence that a person will definitely get into these Ivy League schools. With schools these selective, it's too much of a crapshoot to be certain. I have seen many friends and seniors that are just as, or even more, qualified than I am who were rejected (intentionally not being specific here to protect their privacy). I'd advice against listening to anyone that tries to convince you otherwise. This is not a 100% meritocratic process. 2. According to my college advisor (the guy has been working on admissions for 5+ years as far as I know), it won't matter a lot that you speak 5 languages unless you have the exams to show it (SAT IIs, APs etc). I was wondering about the same thing too (4 languages). There is only a little section on the Common App where we get to write down the languages we know + rough levels of mastery. Take the exams if you can! 3. Don't forget to make sure that your recs and essays are also good. Basic advice really, but they really are important. I still remember an application of a Harvard prospective my counsellor showed me. That dude's a genius. 800 SATs, 5s on who knows how many APs, perfect GPA, summer research with MIT prof, glowing rec from his math teacher ('he is the smartest student I have ever taught') etc. There was one letter from his humanities teacher, though, that completely obliterates everything by discussing his character (I think it was something like his aloofness and his lack of compassion/empathy). He was rejected. Granted he probably got into at least one super good school, but damn. If I were him I would have thought I'd be admitted.  Just choose wisely who you want to write recommendations for you, and give them a lot of time to do so. Also give yourself a lot of time for essays. How much is 'a lot' probably depends on your work pace. Mine took a few months overall. Damn the tendency to be a perfectionist. 4. This is related to #1: don't only apply to the Ivy Leagues (also extends to other very selective schools like Stanford/MIT/Chicago/Caltech etc.) I don't want this (Rejection from all Colleges.  No acceptance yet.) to happen to anyone.  Let me know if you have questions. Best of luck! Who knows, maybe I'll see you around in the next few years. :) Disclaimer: I am not an expert on college admission. This is simply a genuine advice from someone who recently went through the process. If anyone disagrees with what I wrote, please comment to let me know!

Log off Quora. You already know what you have to do. Now do it: Good grades, really good grades.Be actively involved in a couple things you truly want to be involved. Do it from middle school through high school: Scouting, a sport where you’re not a star, photography for the school paper.Work (for money to help your family) at something unusual.Do something so well in school that your teacher has to say you were just unlike any other student.Be an outlier: the gay tuba player from Montana who also runs 100 yards at 10.0 seconds. (That is sarcastic, but I think you know what I mean.)Don’t do stuff everyone else does: the Habitat for Humanity thing in whatever Central American country is still safe. The project has its own rewards: Some family gets a house to live. And you work alongside cute girls or guys in tank tops (unless you go on a church-sponsored trip, in which case it’s T-shirts, not tank or halter tops. Choose carefully.).Have an incredible story about what you’ve overcome: single parent household, not a lot of money, an auto accident that made you learn to walk again. Thing is, other applicants have had something special that they’ve overcome, and you can’t come across sounding like you’re playing a sympathy music violin in the background.Be prepared to be enrolled someplace else. Smaller undergrad school schools like Bowdoin are just about as good. Tufts, Amherst, Williams, Wesleyan are as good and it’s just as hard. Nothing wrong with Colgate, or Union, Lehigh or Bucknell. Or SUNY Geneseo - thinking of schools in the area of the Ivy footprint. Also: Small schools need students who do something else. If you play tuba well enough to be in the school band or orchestra, then you’ve filled a slot. Or if you were news editor of your HS paper or yearbook and plan to do that in college, then you’ve filled a slot. If you’re a jock, being a likely starter moves you to the head of the line (85% chance of acceptance at Harvard if you’re a recruited athlete) and/but at a small school (pay attention here to the math): Say the school is 2,000 students, has 20 sports (10 men, 10 women) and each sport needs 25 athletes, then the school needs 500 athletes who won’t embarrass the school academically. If you are good enough to make the team even if you don’t start, and if you are good enough to be able to maintain a personal GPA that boosts the team GPA, you are someone the school could use. Many sports need a manager. At an Ivy school (I know this section is about small schools), a HS football team manager who really wanted to help manage the university team, the coach used one of his wildcards to make sure the kid got in. Even if you get the coach to put in a good word for you, it helps with the admissions committee. If you’re a minority, well hot damn: You fill three slots at once - student, jock/tuba player/manager, and minority. Some of the Ivies actively look for transfers who aced two years at community college. Apply to Tulane right now if you’re from the Northeast. A top 50 school, still hurting from people who think Hurricane Katrina washed away the campus. Good students from the Northeast often hear by Thanksgiving. You’ve got a great school in the bag and you’re in great shape even if all eight Ivies and MIT say no. You may also have work to do at home: If your parents believe only the Ivy League is what you have to attain or the family name is ruined, start preparing them now. The Ivies admit at best one in ten applicants and it’s approaching or past one in twenty at Harvard, Yale, Princeton (also at Cornell’s College of Arts and Sciences, so don’t think of Cornell as a safety school). If your family is first generation American, maybe they’ve put too much pressure on you. Out of the approximately 4,000 colleges / universities in the US, there are fifty that give the Ivies a good run for their money. When I applied to college, I never would have considered BU and now there’s no chance I could get in. BU just blew by Boston College on the WS Journal ratings, and BC is no slouch either. My barber, who came to the US from Italy with not much, offers this: Every school is a good one if you pay attention. Last thing: Consider a gap year and do something really memorable, not just bum around the Caribbean tending bar.

Thanks for the A2A, Peter! You’ve ticked all the right boxes, but no one can guarantee you a spot in the Ivy League, or in any school that accepts less than a quarter of their students. Some thoughts: You won’t be the only classical pianist in the application pile. If you’re going to write about piano, you need to find the story that is uniquely yours. Every one of them has a “I was doubting myself the night of my Carnegie Hall debut, but I played through the fear and did awesome!” essay and/or a “Music helped me communicate with people I had X language/cultural barrier with.” You will really have to dig to make that fresh. Your goal is a final essay that not only sounds just like you but is a story only you can tell. A good college counselor can help you uncover that.You have great numbers, but coming from a school that sends students to the Ivies every year means you will be competing directly with the other students from your class that are applying to the same programs. The schools just aren’t going to admit ten students from the same high school.I see you attended the USN Summer Academy. Are you applying to Annapolis? Have you considered applying for the ROTC scholarships at your Ivies? Almost no one does, so that can certainly differentiate you.Unless you’re planning to major in piano performance, I don’t see any extracurriculars that show experience with your potential major. If you are planning to major in piano performance, there are probably better fit schools outside the 8 Ivy League schools. (Northwestern comes to mind.)Be sure to sit down with your college counselor to discuss these issues. :-)

Getting into Ivy League University is difficult yet possible if you are willing to work hard. I was able to get into Brown and I did not do anything extraordinary. Some steps to consider to get into an Ivy League University: Narrow down your school list. Spreading yourself too thin by applying to all Ivy League schools or a huge list of schools, will signal to schools that you are less invested in their school. In turn it is less likely to get the attention of admissions decision makers when you apply. Schools want to feel special and try to only admit students that will ultimately attend the school.Be able to meet the minimum standards for the school. Schools publish the profile of the incoming freshman class. This is a good indicator of thresholds needed for test scores, gpa, rank and other stats. Having a really low gpa or falling below median percentile in any category is a red flag. You will also raise a red flag if you do not have outside school activities even though you are extraordinary in other categories. Sometimes these red flags can be explained during the essay portion of the application. And PLEASE make sure to address these red flags in every interaction with the school. Keep working towards at least meeting the median standards but shoot for exceeding each category.Work towards becoming a well-rounded individual. Another way to say this is to get involved in a wide range of activities. If you are not athletic, at least attempt to be part of a sports team. If you are afraid of public speaking try to speak in front of others. This will not only help increase your confidence but also make you more interesting to the school. Prestigious schools like students that can have a wide range of interests. Keep working on your weaknesses because this will show that you are well rounded and willing to take risks.Have a unique story. This is really difficult to explain but there is something that makes you unique and try to highlight this characteristic. For example, my parents did not graduate high school yet I was on the track to becoming valedictorian. This is what I kept reiterating in my application and during my interviews because I knew that is what made me unique. Keep searching, we all have unique qualities. You will just need to reflect and continue to highlight.Show your passion for the school. This is probably the single most important step. For example, you may be a great candidate for both Harvard and Stanford. You apply to both schools but for whatever reason Harvard is interested in you but not Stanford. If your top school is Stanford and did not show passion for attending Harvard, guess what? Harvard admissions team will probably figure this out! Your enthusiasm is a key indicator for the schools. Showing a passion for the school when they are also interested can seal the deal. Think about it, from the admissions officer’s point of view. If they are looking at 2 candidates: one that shows a great passion for attending and another one that is just interested. Guess who will get the admissions packet?Securing an admissions to a prestigious college is never guaranteed. Sometimes it's difficult to understand why people are rejected because schools do not provide feedback. Nonetheless the steps above will help in increasing your chances to get accepted.

I’ve said it before and I’ll say it again. There is no simple formula that you can follow to get into an Ivy League school. If there was, then getting into an Ivy League college wouldn’t be as difficult or impressive. That being said, there are ways to make yourself a more competitive applicant. Here are 4 key ways to know if you qualify for top schools. Academics are an important piece of the equation for top schools. When they are looking for students, they will look at many different parts of your academic track record. Of course, they will look at your overall GPA, but they will also look into what types of classes you are taking. Are you challenging yourself to the highest level? They will look to see if there is an upward trajectory with your grades. They will take into account your class size when looking at your class rank. Your relationships are also an important factor here. Are you a legacy? If so, it’s not always an easier route. They will expect you to know the university better than other applicants and have higher scores than your peers. Your recommenders also play a tremendous role in the admissions process. Your letters of recommendation are the only time that admissions officers are seeing an objective point of view on your candidacy. If you can have fantastic letters of recommendation, it will make a difference. Your essays play a critical role. Your personal statement should show your unique perspective and what you care most about! Your extracurriculars should align with your personal statement and show that you are motivated and passionate about what you’ve pursued. Your supplemental essays need to be tailored to the specific school that you’re applying to. Overall, Ivy League colleges read applications holistically. There is no single factor that guarantees admission or rejection. Try to be the best student you can be and if you excel in the areas listed above, then apply for Ivies and cross your fingers!

I think you have a good shot, but I don't think you will be able to easily get into the Ivy Leagues due to your GPA and 25th~50th percentile ACT score. You have pretty good extra-curriculars, so that's fine. I recommend that you write good essays and integrate your focused interest in majors within your essays wisely.  Furthermore, aside from GPA and test scores, I think demonstrating a focused interest and "fit" to the specific college is crucial. Not only that, but I personally believe that good college essays are a huge factor towards college acceptance.  For example, in terms of demonstrating my interest in Cornell's College of Human Ecology, I made sure to put lots of importance in writing good college application essays and joining major-specific extra-curriculars. There's a supplement essay on CommonApp for Cornell University where I was able to do that. Is this applicant really a good "fit" for this school? Does this applicant do specific EC's and demonstrate SPECIFIC interest in certain majors of this college?"-- These are some questions that admissions officers might ask. And I kept these questions in mind when I wrote my essays. One strong aspect of my application was that my EC's were extremely focused on my major, Human Development, rather than all scattered around. I did gerontology research, Alzheimer's research, and specific sports that demonstrated my interest in sports medicine also. So..yeah. I focused extra-curriculars and compelling essays play a huge role in being able to get that acceptance letter. Of course, however, it is also important to have good GPA and good standardized test scores. Oh, and it's also important to reach out to good teachers who are confident in being able to write a stellar letter of recommendation for you. Good luck! :)

You can. But whether or not you will is an entirely different question. As I have said elsewhere, the number of applicants to Ivies is staggering, when one considers the odds of getting in. Also, admissions is only partly a numbers game; it is a far more subjective business than most applicants realize. Many applicants will have your numbers. Perhaps most of them will. And of course they will have terrific LORS too. The students who get in are different from those who don't often because they have communicated who they are to an admissions committee in a way that makes them unique, fascinating, likeable. Often this comes across in the LORS, but the essay is the golden opportunity to show yourself in this light. And there is no one way to do this. Presenting your best, most authentic self is always the right way to proceed, and then you must let the chips fall where they may. Decide carefully which Ivies to which you will apply, btw. They are not all the same, and they appreciate it when you demonstrate thoughtfulness in deciding where and why to apply. You will land in the place you are supposed to be. Perhaps that will be an Ivy. Perhaps not. It will all be all right, as you get out what you put in, wherever you go. Best of luck!

Getting into an Ivy League college is tough. In the admissions ball game, you are only as good as you are on paper. Although you may have spent hours on a particular activity in high school, if you do not capture that in the application in a meaningful manner, then you have done nothing in the admission officer's eyes. And that means writing stellar application essays. Of course, getting tip top grades, strong SAT, SAT Subject, and AP test scores, and strong leadership and extracurricular activities help significantly with the process. In this day and age, getting those is almost required and a minimum threshold to get in. Pursue activities that demonstrate your well roundedness and that you’re passionate about - we’ve all heard that over and over again. But you didn’t need me to tell you that, did you? So why do these amazing, well-qualified people still get rejected every year? Because they didn’t know how to write their personal statement. Let me tell you, getting into an Ivy League college depends on how well you carve together that college application and demonstrate those personal qualities through the personal statement. The personal statement is the one differentiating factor that separates the 1600 SAT, 4.0 GPA student from the one who has a 1580 SAT and 3.9 GPA at the same high school. These stats are no longer “good enough” to differentiate one candidate from another - rather, they are typical scores and grades that the Ivy Leagues expect you to get. In fact, I will bet that a student with a lower score, say 1300 SAT and 3.8GPA with a stellar application and well written personal statement has a better shot than the 1600 SAT student with a poorly written personal statement at getting into the Ivy League. Princeton, my alma mater, states every year that if they could fill their entire class with valedictorians or 1600 SAT score students, they could do so easily. So how can you get into the Ivy League? Carve together a well thought out college application and personal statement that reflects the qualities that define you.

Thank you for the A2A. I would very much encourage you to look at range of schools outside of the top 50 universities and colleges. I am not saying you should not apply to any of these schools, but I am saying that any of these schools will fall into the reach category. I am not trying to be mean; I am just trying to be pragmatic based on knowing students who have been accepted to Ivies in recent years.  Almost all the students who are admitted to elite schools have exceptionally strong academic programs, top grades and high SAT/ACT scores. The occasional exception to this are what are called hooked students. These are students who are given special consideration. Among these groups are athletes, a few development cases and legacies, and  some who would add diversity to the class, and a few with special talents. Virtually all other students are outstanding  as far as all the numbers go. Your business acumen might fall into the special talent category, but you would have to have a great pitch in your application, interviews and recommendations.  To give just one example of what these school expect here are, the average SAT scores of students accepted to Penn (which I picked because of its business program): SAT Critical Reading	690-780 SAT Math	710-800 SAT Writing	700-790 ACT Composite	32-35 Testing means for the middle 50 percent of admitted students The bottom 25% of accepted students have below  a 2100. Your 1710 would put you  below the bottom 10% of those admitted. Your gpa also seems low compared to the almost all A's that most students have who are offered a spot. Even though you have business experience that far exceeds most students, your academics might give schools significant concern as to whether you can do well in a very competitive academic environment.  The good news is  that there are  untold thousands of very successful people who did not attend an Ivy or a super elite school. What is important is that you develop the skills you need wherever you go.  Best of luck

How can I get into an Ivy League college? You can “get in” if your parents have made enormous donations and have had a building or two with their names on them. You can “get in” if your parents are very famous. Celebrities or politicians. You can “get in” if you would be what’s termed, “a legacy.” (Your parents are alums of the Ivy League college to which you apply.) Of course, having excellent grades, excellent admission tests, and having some kind of special “talent” or “skill” that impresses the college. Also, writing an excellent letter to the admissions committee of the college can help you “get in.” And now for a question for you: What is your motivation for “getting in?” Have you visited Ivy League colleges in person? If so, did you sense a “good fit” for you? Have you talked with students and alums of Ivy League colleges? If so, did what they have to say feel like a “good fit?” Oh, I almost forgot this next “get in” possibility for you. Let the college know that you would take an “early admission.” In other words, you’ll immediately take an admission offer, if given an opportunity, rather than waiting around to see if you get “better” college acceptance letters. Sometimes colleges will accept a student who has applied if they know, for sure, that s/he’ll commit to their school. Schools sometimes offer admission to these kind of applicants because it helps the schools to know ahead of time the number of students that they’ll still have to consider for admission. An early acceptance student is a “sure thing” for admissions staff and it makes their work less stressful for them. Most likely, you already know this next statement. But it’s worth repeating. Make sure that you have a “safe” school in the event you aren’t accepted to higher, more competitive college.

Thanks for the A2A. It’s disconcerting to hear about highly qualified people who didn’t make it into their top choice schools. Unfortunately, there are a lot of those stories, as top schools are more selective than ever. However, if you have excellent qualifications, you can avoid this kind of disappointment by understanding the nature of the acceptance process and also by being flexible and not pinning all your hopes on one or two specific schools. Getting into an Ivy League or other top school is not a matter of playing the odds. Luck can sometimes play a role, but properly qualified people do get in. You need to get a good understanding of what it takes. Visit the schools; talk to the tour guides and anyone else you can find. You’ll get a lot of general information, but try to fish for specifics, not grades and test scores (the numbers are readily available online), but factors like extracurriculars and other activities and talents that the individual might have. Look at a lot of schools (there are a number of highly ranked schools that aren’t in the Ivy League whose degrees command just as much respect), and try to focus on whether they might be right for you. Ignore the rankings and opinions you hear from friends or relatives. For example, everyone knows that Harvard is a great place, but just because it has a gold-plated reputation doesn’t mean it’s the right school for everyone, and I’m aware of people who got in and then transferred out because they realized that. You’ll wind up with a list of schools you’re happy with, and when the replies come out, you won’t be among those complaining on College Confidential.

There are too many variables to this equation, however I'll try my best to summarize three years of searching and hard work. First let me state that, I wasn't accepted at any of the ivy league you mentioned but that's due to a weakness I realized I had but couldn't fix because it was too late, however I got into Rice University which was from my top choices and was also waitlisted by Columbia, Brown, Upenn and around 6 Liberal arts college. Later I was accepted from one of the three former waitlists but I still chose to attend Rice University. You see, Ivy league colleges aren't normal boring colleges right? So don't expect them to admit normal boring people. You must have something to add, a story to tell, a dream to fulfill, a talent to nurture. You must have something, you can't just be the average Jo and get in, it's almost practically impossible to see someone just average and plain I'm Harvard; well there you go that's what you have to do, find a “spike” and grow it. HOWEVER, the above is true given that you have stellar grades and GPA showing that you can actually survive there. Okay, I guess you're now asking, how do you practically show that spike? It's really simple: find a passion and pursue it. For example(it's not merely limited to that example it's just for the purpose of expressing my point), someone may realize at their freshman year that they are deeply interested in mathematics and they learn about the math Olympiad so they join a math course, a summer course or a math circle to develop their skills, they apply to a summer research program by their Junior or sophomore year and later that year publish a research paper, they participate in the olympiad in the summer of the junior year and bam they get a USAMO/IMO Gold, now that's a superstar he pursued his interest and succeeded, that doesn't mean that olympiad medals mean instant-acceptance that's just an example on how someone can pursue his interest and show a spike. EDIT: I'm adding another example, as the aforementioned Olympiad example is probably well-known. One student may have a deep interest in business and entrepreneurship, so he may in his freshman year get stellar grades in business, then apply for an internship and get accepted and taste the practical aspects of the business, then later he may have an idea about a start up that he want to pursue, then during his sophomore year he may have obtained fund and started working on it, later on he was accepted into LaunchX and by the end of his junior/senior year he has a business that's operating and is actually helping the community, now that's a nother superstar, and the list of ways to stand out is infinitely long. Given that you mix that with passionate, thoughtful, well written essays and above average SAT/ACT scores you're ready to go. Don't hesitate to message me anytime if you have any other questions! Feel free to follow me on Instagram: Abdelrahman Abouzeid (@aaabouzeid) • Instagram photos and videos

A2A. That’s the million dollar question, isn’t it? First of all, there are a few things you need to ‘check off,’ so to speak. High grades in the most rigorous and difficult classes available to you.Very high test scores. Ideally 33+ on the ACT, 730+ on SAT sections.Extraordinary extracurriculars. This doesn't mean, do the most impressive thing for colleges. It means do the most impressive thing for yourself. Discover your interests and pursue them to the highest level available to you. If there isn't a high level available to you, make it yourself. Carve your own path.Sports. Even if you aren't planning to be a student-athlete, try to have at least one sport in your activities list. You don't have to be super intense and be on your school’s team. Pick something for fun, like yoga, or amateur soccer with your friends. Besides being another extracurricular, it shows that you are an active individual who cares about your health. My Princeton interviewer flat out told me that nearly every student admitted did some sort of sport in high school, and that not playing one was a serious deterrent in admissions.Awesome teacher recommendations. Best-student-in-my-career kind of recommendations. Be friends with your teachers to garner that kind of glowing review.Want more advice? I wrote out a sarcastic, semi-satirical high schooler’s ‘master plan’ guide to Ivy League admissions here: Remi Lewis's answer to Should I be planning for college as a freshman in highschool?

For the best colleges, having perfect “stats” (grades, scores, etc.) does not necessarily mean a student is “well-qualified”. Think about it this way: if all the colleges cared about were grades and scores, then why would they have you go through the whole application process?!? Kids with 34+ ACT/1500+ SAT, straight A’s in the hardest classes, tons of APs… who attend the best high schools in the country routinely get rejected by the best colleges. Why? Well, there are literally thousands of these kids applying to all the top schools… and it’s hard to tell them apart by just looking at “stats”. Top schools can’t and don’t want to admit all of them. Don’t get me wrong: grades and scores are certainly important. But you will need more than perfect grades and scores to get in. Think of the other parts of your application that can help you stand out. Extracurricular activities are very important. Keep in mind that colleges look for “well-rounded” applicants, those whose extracurriculars include some “group” (student government, sports, community service) and some “individual” (music, academic competitions, honor societies) activities. However, if you’re a superstar in something (say, you’re a one of the best piccolo players in the U.S.) that will trump the need for well-roundedness. Most applicants, however, need some balancing. Worth noting here that a part-time job counts (in my mind) as an extracurricular activity and should definitely be mentioned especially if it’s done during the school year. Anything that shows you can balance schoolwork with a solid commitment to other things helps your case. Do not pad your resume with activities for the sake of activities. Find a few things you enjoy and do them, well. You don’t necessarily need to be a “leader”. Colleges value good “team members” as well, particularly those who demonstrate grittiness, hard work, etc. There’s also what I like to call the “good character” test. Colleges want to build a harmonious class of students who will get along with each other and who will learn/grow with each other. Harvard’s website asks the question: “would other students want to share a meal or a dorm with this student?” Colleges typically find the answer to that question in teacher and counselor recommendations, so its important that the people writing them speak to your non-academic qualifications as well as your academic ones. Other things that affect your chances that are out of your control: colleges look for economic and racial diversity. They give preference to first generation college students, applicants with an interesting backstories (especially those who overcame significant adversity), and legacy applicants.

The eight Ivy League institutions are Brown University, Providence, RI; Columbia University, New York, NY; Cornell University, Ithaca, NY; Dartmouth College, Hanover, NH; Harvard University, Cambridge, MA; Princeton University, Princeton, NJ; the University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA; and Yale University, New Haven, CT. Yes, you have a chance if you apply. You have no chance if you don’t apply. Look at the web sites of each of the Ivies and decide on your top three choices after you review the programs each offers that interest you, the student body size and population, the faculty:student ratios, the facilities, the cost, the geographic areas in which they’re located, and so forth. If possible, visit the three you choose and have a campus tour. Complete each institution’s application materials. Think carefully about the questions the application asks. You need to put your best foot forward while completing the application honestly, carefully, and accurately and provide all the information each one seeks. Most, if not all, of the Ivies include an in-person interview with an alum living hear you as part of the admission process. However, all the Ivies are highly competitive for undergraduate admission, so acceptance isn’t guaranteed.

I'm finishing the high school, and I want to apply to some Ivy Leagues (Stanford, Harvard, Yale). I wonder tips to join these universities. Thank You  Note: I'm 16, I will apply 18 years old, but already I want to prepare with community service, scientific fairs, things that complement its historic for these universities. As a Harvard admissions interviewer, I think you are going about it the wrong way. Don't do things that you think we (Harvard admissions) will like. Do things that you are passionate about. Spend the next two years pursuing your interests as far as you can, overcoming whatever challenges that you encounter, handling any setbacks that occur. It's that focus, zeal and doggedness that we are looking for. Here are my answers to similar questions. Arvin Chang's answer to I'm in high school right now in Australia and I would like to have a well-rounded resume for Harvard. What are some things I should participate in? Arvin Chang's answer to Do MIT, Harvard and Stanford (elite colleges) only look for GPA, SAT and ACT as a main deal or the things the children have done that are difficult and abnormal?
