Admission to the Ivy League schools, as well as Stanford, MIT, and Caltech, have become increasingly competitive. At Penn, there were 38,000 applications for about 2,000 spots in this years upcoming Freshman class. Even back in the day when I attended Penn, it was well known the University could easily fill the entire class with students just from say New York with perfect or near perfect grades, SAT scores, and outside activities and talents. The joke was you needed to be able to play the tuba with one hand and your eyes shut to have a shot at getting in. You need the metrics. You need the grades and SAT scores which are competitive for these schools. If you fall short, then there needs to be some reason the scores are not where they should be. Typically, it is an extraordinary long shot if this is not in place to start. Second, you need strong extracurricular activities. The best level of participation is a leadership position, which typically means being President of the organization. Third, you ideally want some of your extracurricular activities to be athletic activities. The Ivy League schools do not offer athletic scholarships, but students who show leadership, creativitiy and accomplishment through athletics are well admired. It would be nice if I could be Katie Ladecky. Fourth, it is extremely helpful to have strong letters of recommendation. Letters help tie together pieces of the application. The letters are also a way for the real leaders to stand out among the many many students vying for these few select spots.

Mihir Chakravarti got the basic points. I'd add that the colleges are tending to get more savvy towards people who fill their application resumes with padding, so if you're going to do something, make it a real commitment. Plus, everyone hates the sort of guy who's doing things just to pad their resume - do you really want to be that sort of person? I'd honestly recommend working on one or two projects on the side, whatever interests you. Is it trying to make a game mod? Is it building a kinetic sculpture? Is it learning folk songs from old folks who live in your area? While intelligence helps, a lot of success in college and beyond is a certain doggedness; the ability to try something, persevere, give up after a long night of nothing working and then start right up again the next morning. I've had a few professors tell me that they love hiring people who grew up on ranches/farms into their labs because they are the sort of people to "get things done". I've had a guy from a National Lab telling me that he loves hiring musical people because these people already demonstrated that they stuck with a difficult, frustrating thing FOR YEARS. Even if you're not doing something so grand as winning the Intel Science Fair, really showing the sort of commitment to a project and being able to talk about it* will serve you very well. Particularly, you'll want something where you can talk about what you learned, if your project changed from your initial idea and how you dealt with that, and what you might do differently the next time. I'd note that I'm speaking as a scientist/engineer, so my answer may be a bit off if you're looking at getting into the humanities, fine arts, etc. If you can tell me what sort of field you're looking at getting into I could give some more specific advice. *There's two opportunities you'll really get to talk about this: in your college admissions essay and a personal interview, if you can get one arranged. Pretty much every major college will have an interviewer in your local area, generally someone who's an alumnus. If not, it's likely you'll meet one if you go on a campus visit.

An Ivy League? There is only one. To get in, you need to be qualified. This means high GPA, high SAT scores. You need to interview well, extracurriculars help, but are mainly used to show that you are well rounded. Once qualified, they see how you fit into the class. This means that a well qualified applicant from Wyoming has a slightly better chance than a well qualified applicant from Manhattan, since there are lots of qualified applicants from Manhattan. Similarly, a well qualified Native American may have an advantage over a well qualified Asian, for the same reason. These schools turn down more qualified applicants than they accept. The important thing to realize is that if you don’t get into an Ivy League school, you can still get into a great school. The top graduate schools give a better education than good ones. But any school in the top 50 will give you a similar quality education on the undergraduate level. The main things that you should look for when choosing one of these schools is whether or not your major is offered, and if it is the right environment for you. Some other schools actually have better teaching on the undergraduate level, because they don’t concentrate their efforts on graduate students. I will match my undergraduate education (Villanova — ranked 45) with any school. I was still able to get accepted at several elite schools for graduate work (I turned down an Ivy League school, but have graduate degrees from Duke and Berkeley).

Thanks for the A2A. Btw, if you are currently a CO 2023 applicant, join the group chat for applicants now! Here’s how - download Mascot, search “Yale” and join the group! Current college students: welcome to start your own group and help answer questions about your college! - 1. Start early. If you have time the summer before senior year, this can be a great time to get a head start on your Common App essay. This will give you more time to reflect on your draft and revise more thoughtfully, rather than scrambling at the last minute to make changes. Trust me, it will also save you stress if you have a buffer of a few days built in, just to accommodate for any final pieces you want to change and to avoid concerns like “what if my Internet doesn’t work at 11:55PM the day of the deadline when I’m trying to submit!” 2. Stay organized. Know when deadlines are for various schools. Know what supplementary materials you may need (or have the option to include) at each. Set up a reasonable schedule for finishing extra essays or administrative details which ensures that you get everything done, but won’t become overloaded. If you must copy and paste a certain essay, because it happens to fit more than one school’s prompt really well (I generally advise being very thoughtful with every essay, but there were a couple of times I copy/pasted simply because schools’ supplemental materials happened to be essentially identical), don’t forget to change school-specific details! 3. Maintain a healthy balance of following parents’, teachers’, and friends’ advice versus ignoring it. All of it is well-intentioned, of course, and it can often be helpful. However, simply following every piece of advice you’re going to it will lead to 2 key problems. First of all, you will often receive conflicting advice—someone will say, “focus more on your piano activities than your Boy Scout activities!” while others will say “focus more on your Boy Scout activities than on your piano activities!” Each will have valid reasons, but always changing things around can lead to unnecessary work. And you have to ask yourself: does it really matter which you focus on more, if they’re both significant and interesting parts of your life? Probably not. The second issue that can arise, is that if all of your application is heavily tailored based on others’ advice, you risk no longer sounding like your true, authentic self. To avoid both of these issues, I advise that if it’s a small, nit-picky suggestion that you don’t immediately agree with (e.g. this wouldn’t apply to a clear grammatical mistake), ignore it. If it’s a big picture thing where you don’t immediately disagree, spend some time thinking about what this change might look like, implement it in a separate version, and compare the two on your own terms, or with a different person. 4. Don’t forget to enjoy senior year! There is a good chance that you and your friends from high school will end up scattered at schools across the country. As exciting as college is (and as stressful as the application process may seem), don’t let this get in the way of enjoying the last few months spending quality time with those you’ve become closest to.

You are 100% wrong to obsess about the Ivy League. Certainly, apply, but realize that there are a thousand excellent schools where you might be much happier, and where you will get a first-rate education and also lay the foundation for great success in life. Admission to an Ivy League school is absolutely no guarantee of success. Know yourself. What environment best suits you and your learning style. Small school with small classes and attentive faculty (Reed, Swarthmore, Carlton, Grinnell, Bryn Mawr), large research university with many opportunities for collaboration with top-ranked faculty (Minnesota, Michigan, UCLA, Indiana), urban school (Macalester, Wayne State, Carnegie-Mellon, NYU), rural/small-town college (Antioch, Kenyon, Middlebury, Dennison), southern (Tulane, Rollins, University of Alabama, University of Texas, Trinity University) northern (Bowdoin, Bates, Michigan Tech, Binghamton, Rochester). All of these and more are great schools where you will succeed. If you somehow fixate on the Ivy League, you are only setting up a false goal. Your goal should be to get a great education for a great career, and there are so many opportunities to do this if take care and make the choice that is right for YOU.

Unfortunately, there’s no straight or simple answer to this. But i can give you an outline: have as good of an SAT/ACT score as possible. Above 1550 will be a good range (for SAT). 33–36 for ACT. and the closer to perfect the better, as it can help you.take the highest rigor at your school, and do well too. Take honors courses, and, if your school offers these, IB or APs.Have a high GPA. Try to get your unweighted GPA to as close to a 4.0 as possible. And your weighted as close to a 5.0 as possible.Show committment and success in ECs, and have good ones too. Not only should you be involved in things that make you stand out, you should try to show leadership or skill or anything that makes you stand out within the activity as well.Show your “story” in your essays. Make sure who YOU are stands out. And it doesn’t hurt to show your well-rounded-ness in them either.You want to be a well-rounded student with a spike. So you want to do other things, like service, to make you seem like a full circle. But that won’t get you to an Ivy these days. You need to really be special in something, or quite special in a couple things, you get the idea. To do this, simply pursue your interests and go as far as you can with them. (Ex: if you like business, maybe make your own!- and also be apart of business-y clubs).Sorta unrelated point: If you get interviewed or have to write something about why the school fits you, make sure you’ve done your research and can give reasons why that school is a better fit for you than another, as well as why you are a better fit for it than another.It seems really easy when you look at it like this. Of course, actually doing these things… can be challenging. But also fulfilling, because, as you’ll notice, even if you don’t get into an Ivy- and that’s extremely ok- you would have (hopefully) strengthened your interests, abilities, habits like work effort, and overall high school experience. Just put YOUR soul into all that you do, and you’ll go where you belong. You got this.

There isn’t any one answer for this since students who study in the Ivys generally show their excellence in different ways. However, there are a few general rules to follow. If you want to get into the Ivys, you should start preparing from the beginning of 11th grade. Anytime after that is too late. First, always maintain good grades. This is the most crucial point. Your school marks from 11th grade onward is the factor that admissions officials will check first. If your scores are good, only then will they proceed into the bulk of your application. Always be in the top 10% of your class. Second, plan your extracurriculars wisely. These are the basis for the essays you will have to write which form the bulk of your application. There isn’t any single formula, but try to do something that benifits society. They love that kind of stuff. If you have a particular hobby, say guitar, maybe create some sort of music class. Or play for the elderly. One of my seniors got admission into Wharton. He was school captain, the founder and president of two nonprofit organisations, started a Model United Nations and cofounded a web development company (that actually made quite a bit of money). See, the ECs have to be on point if you want to go to the world’s best. (but you don’t really have to be as good as this guy). Third, start writing your college essays well in advance. These will be read very thoroughly as they are the most important factor in securing admission. They will contain all of your achievements and goals for the future, etc. There are plenty of websites available which give guidelines for writing these. My senior who is now in Wharton took two months writing and editing for four to five hours a day doing this. Also get good letters of recommendation from your principal, teachers, etc. Fourth, Give the SAT and Subject SATs and score as high as possible. Don’t waste your time giving more than two attempts each. They aren’t as important as the other factors. It’s more of a formality. You should get a score of 2150 or higher as per the old SAT (I don’t really know what it is for the new SAT, but the college board does have conversion tables on its official website). Try to get full in the subject SATs. This is easier to do. And most importantly, Do research. Read the official websites. Ask around. There are too many nitty-gritties to be explained in just one answer. Only extensive research can help you decide the best way to get there. No pressure :)

You can start with an analysis of your academic metrics. These include your GPA and class rank if your school ranks coupled with the rigor of courses you are taking or took;two SAT subject tests, one of which should be math if you are interested in a STEM major;your scores on standardized tests that you have taken; andsince I am assuming you are an international student, your English as a second language test results.You should have a standardized test score in the at least the 25th percentile, preferable 75th percentile or higher for the school you want to attend. Your SAT Subject Tests should be in the upper range. A perfect score on the Math 2 test is 800 and 12% of the students who took the test last year had an 800. Your GPA should be over 4.0 if it is weighted which indicates that you have taken honors and college prep courses. If your metrics are in the ball park, you have as they say your foot in the door. But there is much you still have to do to open it completely. You need to create an interesting narrative about yourself that will make the admission officers reading your application want to know more about you and even admit you. You have already started on it in your comments above. The one thing you do need to weigh is how much you want to reveal about your illness. If you are intent on telling the story about a maturing, recovering young adult who battled with depression and illness including anorexia, then I would suggest you emphasize the positives of your recovery and not the negatives of your disease. Ivy League schools are stressful places and you don’t want to give the admissions officials any room to think that if you were admitted you might succumb to the pressures and once again sink into depression. Depression on campus is a serious issue and university officials are struggling with how to cope with it.

You have a good story to tell, and I hope you get the opportunity to tell it. Unfortunately, sometimes admissions are such that if you don’t have the scores and the courses, you don’t get that chance. You didn’t mention your SAT scores and achievement tests, and if you want to get into a physics department your math courses will be important. The things you are doing in addition to coursework are very impressive and certainly show you to be someone who can make a positive contribution to the school. One issue might be how much of your coursework will be accepted by the university. Are you willing to go for another 3 years instead of 2? Obviously, finances are an issue. Also, rather than trying to get into a school based on the reputation, find out which of the schools make a transition from another college relatively painless. Sometimes that transition is actually easier with a larger school (like my school, Cornell). (Unfortunately, while I love Cornell and respect many of the physics professors, I do not recommend the undergraduate physics department and would suggest looking at engineering physics or theoretical and applied mechanics.) I think you have a fair chance of being accepted to one or more of the schools you identified. Harvard and Princeton - probably not. Cornell - maybe. Georgia and U of M - yes. Good luck.

Anything is possible, but nothing is guaranteed. Top colleges are super competitive. Also—your demographics play a big role. If your high school is a “feeder” for a school, you especially will have a difficult time. However, be confident in your abilities. What are you really good at? Can you build better snowmen than anyone else? Can you herd cats? Find your gem, and polish it. :) I don’t know how old you are, but it is necessary to get a high GPA and test scores. That’s common sense. The hardest part, by far, of getting into a place so competitive is DIFFERENTIATING yourself. In terms of supply and demand, they turn away 9 kids for every 1 they accept. Some are not so competitive, but you get the idea. So find your gem, polish it, and start telling your story. Let everyone know about your dream of being a professional cat herder. Post videos everywhere. Have something to speak for your talents. Let the cats speak for you.

Simple answer, you need to: Take a very rigorous set of classes from your 9th through 12th gradesAttend a strong secondary school that’s on the radar of all the Ivy League admissions committeesAce those classes and land on the top end of the class you are applying — these days a 4.5 weighted GPA or higher is a good barCrush the ACT or SAT (or both) — 99% or higherScore 5’s on many AP exams or 800s on a good number of subject testsProve you’re incredible (again, ideally the top 1%) at three or more of the following: extra curriculars, sports, community supporting organizations, artistic endeavors, scientific specialties, computer programming, writing and/or speech, debate, or any activity or endeavor the schools recognize or needBe a part of some ethnicity or underrepresented population that the Ivy you’re applying to needsWrite the most compelling and meaningful personal statements and supplementary essays required by the institutionObtain a plethora of accolades by again recognized organizations like winning the national spelling bee or placing (ideally winning) in the Intel Science CompetitionAlso, be able to obtain the best recommendations possible from your instructors over the years (so, you’ll want to cultivate very meaningful and sincere relationships with your teachers)Be some prodigy in an area like the theatre arts, music, the natural sciences, design, architecture, web development, engineering, business, or almost any subject matter that the university again will recognizeOr anything else that can make you so “pointy” that a University will easily recognize your application against the tens of thousands of others competing against you for the limited spotsAnd if you have wealthy parents or a long list of legacy alumni, your chances could be higher if they donated a large sum or sponsored some part of the school in a significant mannner. The legacy advantage is smaller than ever, but it can still help.The other way is find an incredible and effective college consultant who can guide you through the process. They are paid to help you get in. And the good ones will definitely put you in a better position. Also, make sure they are able to spend enough time with you and aren’t loaded up with too many clients because they are mainly in it for the money. Lastly, the earlier you start, the better.

Those eight universities that play sports together in the Ivy Athletic league are all elite private universities that are: Liberal arts centeredRoughly 20% of the undergraduates play an intercollegiate sport to Win.And all of those eight universities (and most of the other elite private US colleges) have a self-imposed Quota on international undergraduate students. Only 10 to 12% of the undergraduates are international and that reduces the overall acceptance rate for international freshman applicants to Less than 3%. Get recruited by one of those eight head coaches of the women’s varsity basketball teams: Ivy League and Ivy League (women’s basketball) And if you are not ready for NCAA D-1 basketball, but can “bring it” for NCAA D-3 basketball, then take a look at the “mini-Ivy league” (NESCAC league): NESCAC (women’s basketball) If you are recruited for Basketball, no one will care that at some point in your Distant past you were anorexic. Just stay with your medical treatment program and chow down with your female team mates at the women’s basketball team meals. And to find out what the top US colleges expect from their successful applicants read this article and the links (especially the report): http://news.mit.edu/2016/stu-schmill-endorses-consideration-of-character-in-college-admissions-0120 All the best.

Never use 3rd party sites or message boards for deadline information! All the information about what is required and when will be on the admission pages of the college itself. There is no substitute. Read all the information on the admissions pages for tips as well as deadlines. Colleges usually accept applications starting in the fall for admission the following fall. Some have optional ED/EA deadlines. Regular deadlines start at year end for most schools but there are colleges that accept application all through the spring. Sometimes you need your application in early if you are applying for aid. Financial aid applications are due at the same time as your admission application or shortly after. There are many exceptions, check the website for each college. Remember that most schools are need blind but do not meet full need (most public colleges fall into this category.) You seem to be talking about need blind schools that will also meet need. If you are an international there are only 6 need blind schools that meet full need.* Yet there are need aware colleges that will meet need if you are accepted. Some schools offer preferential packaging and meet need of just the most desirable students, due to budget constraints. There are other colleges that may give you merit awards. If you are a U.S. citizen or permanent resident there are at least 30 more need blind, meets full need. At at least 60+ that will meet need.  Then there are cases like the UC system that only meets need for instate students who are low income.  I am not sure what 'class 11' is. *See the citation in this Wikipedia article (Amherst, Dartmouth, Harvard, MIT, Princeton and Yale are the only ones that are need blind and meet need guarantee for all students including internationals. This is well known so they get a disproportionate amount of international student applications.)Need-blind admission

Absolutely! Try your best to paint a cohesive picture of yourself will all of these activities. It is important to show that you genuinely care about the things you have done in high school and illustrate how Harvard would be a good fit for you and also how you would be a great addition to the school. Being a national champion definitely helps! It suggests that you have countless self-defining experiences that you can draw upon, so use them to your advantage. Your SAT scores do not matter as much as others would suggest...I know people who have gotten a perfect score but failed to get into top schools. I also know people with sub 2000 scores that have been accepted to top ten schools. Basically, schools want to see that you have the ability to succeed in their environment. Think of an acceptance as an investment, and show that you are committed to making good returns. Mainly, spend time think carefully about all your experiences and use them to depict yourself in the best way possible.

The admissions statistics for the year 2020 for Harvard just like in the previous years show that still getting to Ivy League School is hard. From nearly 40,000 applications, only barely 2,000 will be accepted, which is 5%. To improve the likelihood of getting accepted, besides being an exceptional student with top grades, you need to make an extra effort. Just like you will have to when applying for one of the better trainee jobs at private companies. Reach out to several local alumni for guidance. Perhaps they will be interviewing you during the admissions process. Harvard hires more than 15,000 alumni to help recruit students from all 50 states and from around the world. If you are not lucky and after consulting with the alumni you get examined by somebody else you still have the chance of being recommended form the respected old grad. Don't waste the opportunity. Bear in mind, it's known that the applicants need to demonstrate a fairly pushy nature. You are expected to “move heaven and earth” to get what you want. Source: How to Get into an Ivy League School? — HundredFoot

Get great grades……score in the upper 2% or higher on the SAT Test…..be a genius or close to it……be good in chemistry and calculus and physics….play a musical instrument…..have some charitable program or plan or organization that you started…..have tons of money to pay the part of the tuition not covered by a scholarship…..have an IQ of 160…..just a few things like that will get you into an Ivy League University. On the other hand…if you go to State University…like The 23 California State University System…..the tuition will be about $6000 , you live at home to save money, you have all Phd professors well qualified, you get the same BA or BS as you’d get at The Ivy League….and because the competition for grades will not be as demanding……your GPA will be at least 2 grades higher than if you’re in an Ivy League School so you might even qualify for a Masters Program in an Ivy League U. OK….agree…disagree…??? Up to you!

Getting into elite schools like Harvard, Yale, Princeton, Stanford, and others is a goal of many high school students. How exactly to accomplish this is often a mystery to students and parents going through the admissions process. Lots of unhelpful and vague advice abound, especially from people who have never gained admission themselves to these schools. In high school, I got into every school I applied to, including Harvard, Princeton, MIT, and Stanford, and I attended Harvard for college. I also learned a lot about my classmates and the dynamics of college admissions in ways that were never clear to me in high school. Now, I'm sharing this expertise with you. I’ve written the most comprehensive guide to getting into top schools. I’m going to explain in detail what admissions officers at Ivy League schools are really looking for in your application. More importantly, I’m going to share an actionable framework you can use to build the most compelling application that’s unique to you.

While there's no guaranteed way to get into an Ivy League school, there are a few things you can do to greatly improve your chances. First off, you need to work hard.  Get and maintain high grades all throughout high school, and they to do as well as possible on admissions tests like the SAT and ACT. From there, look for a way to differentiate yourself.  High scholastic achievement is essentially a pre-requisite for the Ivy League; nearly everyone else who applies will have great grades and fantastic test scores too.  In order to stand out from the crowd, you need to have some distinctive talent--and preferably two or three--that makes you special. Finally, think about what Lori Dunlap said in her response: "Why do you want to go there?" Sitting down and thinking about this question has two benefits.  First, it helps you decide if an Ivy League school is really the right fit for you.  Second, if you decide you want to put in the work necessary for Ivy League admissions, a great response to this question can be another way to stand out from the other applicants and give you a leg up. Good Luck!

I'm not an admissions officer but I have reviewed resumes to hire employees. I agree with others; more time on your studies and less on clubs and businesses. You have to be able to perform academically, and a reader has to be able to independently verify that your business is real for it to add value. It is doubtful that you are interested in all 8 clubs equally, or that together they tell some sort of cogent story. How significant are these businesses if you can still belong to 8 clubs (or conversely how meaningful is your club membership)? I see marketing business and I ask myself if this is doing social media for unsavvy local mom and pop shops - it shows that you get out and find paid work that uses your skills, but not necessarily better in my eyes than working consistently for five years in a mom and pop shop or the local grocery chain with advancement.  You are glorifying your activities with titles that might not be justified - marketing business, serial entrepreneur since age 9 (have you launched anything that is nationally known? do these businesses still exist? how significant were they?). Anything that sounds too good to be true is suspect. It isn't that your accomplishments are not worth anything; rather, you need to present them in their true light and more isn't necessarily better.

Remember, even average students can get accepted at top universities because US Universities believe Ordinary Students Can Deliver Extra-ordinary Results, as also Academic Brilliance Need Not Always Translate Into Professional Excellence. Yes, an average student can get into MIT UC Berkley or Stanford. Sounds strange, but possible! All you have to do is, project yourself as a passionate innovator who can bring about new solutions through your out of box thinking. US Universities look for an Einstein, Edison and Tesla inside you. Much more than your academic scores, they are eager to find out the hidden scientist inside you. So, explain in details, your past research projects and future areas of work where you see lot of opportunities. Remember, Edison had been to school for just three months in his lifetime. In middle school, Einstein was a very ordinary student. Thus, the ability to become a scientist depends much more on innovative thinking than on being a class topper. So, think out of box, and you may end up with a path-breaking discovery. So what matters is your passion for the subject and your drive for innovation. By - www.statementofpurpose.co.in

Here’s what a student has to do to get accepted to an Ivy League-no guarantees, just advice. Have strong grades (by strong, I mean aim for perfect 4.0)Solid SAT/ACT (1500 is a nice number to look at )Attend a high school that is valuedCompete on a state, national or international level in some way.Get recruited for a sport in 11th gradeApply early action or early decision (it improves your chance a little)Make sure to pack your summer with high value experience (not “activities” but real research or internship or a selective summer program)Be valued by others and work for other people or on their behalf. I’m not talking about logging hours. I’m saying be there for others and develop a sense of service toward them—in your school and on a larger scale.Think bigger and beyond your school

PLAN WELL IN ADVANCE i.e. FROM HIGH SCHOOL ONWARDSFIRST CROSS THE FILTERS i.e. GRADES/SCORES/TOEFL/SAT/ACT etc. This essentially means that your marks and scores will only get you shortlisted for a review. Incase you do not have the desired scores you will be eliminated and not shortlisted for the next round.ESSAYS AND RECOMMENDATION LETTERS- WHAT SETS YOU APART. WHAT HAVE YOU DONE DIFFERENT/EXTRA. HAVE YOU DEMONSTRATED THAT YOU ARE DRIVEN . THAT YOU ARE A DOER RATHER THAN A TALKER. ARE YOU A RESPONSIBLE MEMBER OF SOCIETY? DO YOU GIVE BACK TO SOCIETY? DO YOU HAVE THE RIGHT ATTITUDE? ARE YOU SOMEONE WHO WILL MAKE A DIFFERENCE TO THE WORLD?THE LAST BUT NOT THE LEAST- HOW WILL YOU ADD TO THE DIVERSITY OF THE CLASSROOM! WHAT WILL YOU BRING TO THE CLASSROOM AS A PERSON? HOW WELL WILL YOU USE THE RESOURSES OF THE UNIVERSITY? ARE YOU THE BEST FIT FOR THE UNIVERSITY AND VISA VERSA!IF YOU HAVE ALL THE ANSWERS TO THE ABOVE QUESTIONS, COVERED IN YOUR APPLICATION , YOU HAVE A CHANCE FOR GETTING INTO AN Ivy League UNIVERSITY!

Don’t worry about Ivy League, think about what you really want, what is your long-term goal, and what you expect after your undergraduate education. There are a lot of good schools in US, most of them do not belong to Ivy League. For example, Stanford, Caltech, Berkeley, MIT, Northwestern, Chicago, Duke, Rice, Johns Hopkins etc. Try to do something toward your goal. And also bear in mind that if your family is super rich and has tons of solid connections, you don’t even need to worry about your profile. You should be able to get into an Ivy League school by default.

This question gets asked a lot. You can find piles answers with a small amount of effort. Rather than add to the pile, i’ll Answer a different question. The Ivy League is not guaranteed for anyone no matter how high-achieving. You might have what it takes. More likely, despite your best efforts, you’ll come up short. This should not be taken as discouragement. Rather, it is a call to action. To be successful, you will have to strive mightily. Not just A’s but A’s in the toughest courses. Not just participation in extracurriculars but leadership and passion. There are lots of bright, hardworking passionate students - more than the 15,000 or so openings in the Ivy League. Nonetheless, if you set your sights on the Ivy League, you’ll achieve better results than if you take an easier path.

I do not know about all the Ivies but to gain admission to mine there are no longer any legacy students. Legacy admission was abandoned a long time ago. Rosemary Labree is not accurate although world class athletes might get better notice than most. Her advice might have been decent 30 years ago but not any longer. John’s answer is the best. Read his list. There is an emphasis from some of the Ivy league schools to accept more public school educated students. There is also a move to accept a more diverse student body. Armed with this, you cannot be accepted unless you send an application. The worst outcome will be a rejection.

How to get into an Ivy League college: Have a parent who got into an Ivy League college.Have a sibling who got into an Ivy League college.Have any other family member who went to an Ivy League college.Come from a family with a lot of money.Come from a family with very little money.Master a fairly rare sport like lacrosse, fencing, tennis, etc.Get decent grades without worrying about a 4.0.Get 1450-1600 on your SAT.Master something exceptional that goes beyond the ordinary extracurricular activities.Write a compelling, unusual, and impressive personal essay.Be yourself in your interview.Show them how you will make their Ivy League school and student body a better place.In short, be a smart, fairly rare, interesting person with something to offer their Ivy League school community.

Your international status will hurt you a lot; at any of the Ivies, acceptance rates for international students are dramatically lower those that of domestics. That said, I'd say you've got a decent chance of getting at least one acceptance. Your scores don't disqualify you and if you present your experiences (with water polo and the volunteer work you did) well, they may be compelling to an admissions committee. Or not. Maybe they'll accept some other national polo champion instead. There's really no way to predict. This is all laying aside the option of being recruited to play water polo, which you should be looking into. The US governing body of college athletics is the NCAA, and if you satisfy their standards for amateur status (NCAA Eligibility Center -- it's a terrible interface, I know), college athletic departments often have a surprising amount of influence on the admissions committee.

Get your other grades up -- this may be job #1Make sure you have very high SAT scoresMake sure you take at least two SAT II tests -- take these now in subjects you just finished and did very well as they're fresh in your mind (less need to cram)Take the AP exams now -- again, less need to cramFind something other than academics in which you can excel -- first chair, all state orchestra; all state soccer team; etc...Find a research project you can work on -- you took college courses so talk to one of your professors and see if you can intern during the summer (or school year)Apply to all the Ivies (and Stanford, MIT, CalTech, UCB, UM, U Chicago, etc...) -- most (don't know if MIT has joined the party yet...) participate in the Common Application.  If money is an issue, you can sometimes get the application fee waved.  You're buying lottery tickets -- increase your odds by buying more tickets.Apply early (but only apply to one where you are contractually bound to attend if admitted)Don't be unhappy about not getting into any Ivies -- there are more qualified applicants than competitive slots -- find a few "backup" schools and at least one "safety" school -- you cannot underestimate the peace of mind of at least one "thick envelope" while all the other wait list letters arrive.

If you are asking in your final year it is almost certainly too late. The Ivy league is a sports league of some very good to some super-elite schools. These schools get so many applications that they can pick and choose. They do not inflate their stats. They all could have higher “stats” if they chose. Do you know how many 4.0 GPA (not corrected) and perfect SAT the super elite schools refuse? If that is all you have, then it is not enough, especially if international. Their first question is “can you do the work and graduate in 4 years?” 50% of applicants pass the test. Then they pick and choose among the applicants. They look for leadership, talent, passion and other factors. If your first view is in your final year of school and you have no leadership positions, no special sports talent, etc. then your chances of getting in are very small.

Start with answering this question:  Why do you want to?  You should invest some time in answering this for yourself, because it will take a lot of time and energy to do what you need to do to be competitive (AP classes, test prep, extra-curricular activities), so you need to know why you're doing all this work and, at some point (most likely) taking on debt to pay for an Ivy League education. In other words, you need to do a cost/benefit analysis before investing yourself in this path. Another reason to answer this question is because admissions officers at these schools will want to know the answer as well. If you don't have a thoughtful, genuine response, it won't matter what your GPA is.

So I’m a junior in high school currently and I really want to get in an ivy. It seems that anything I can't do or get is the end of the world. Like for example, if I don't make past tryouts that start soon for tennis it will significantly hurt my chances. But I know I need to see big picture. My gpa is 3.94 unweighted, I’m top 10 in my class, and I haven't taken the sat or act yet. It’s late to do any prestigious summer programs and I just don't know if theres anything that can increase my chances or appeal to colleges. If it means anything I’m of middle eastern origin and an immigrant.

To be blunt, no, you don't really have a good shot. Preferably, you want your SAT scores to be above 2100.  Your GPA is solid, but is also on the low end of the spectrum.  Entrepreneurship definitely helps when applying, especially if you focus on what you've accomplished through your ventures in your essay. Speaking from personally experience, you need spectacular essays about entrepreneurship and the GPA and scores to back it up. Since you're slightly lacking in the latter part, it'll be hard for admissions to see you as a good academic fit for the Ivies.

It's too late to add extracurricular activities; almost every college that sees activities added at application time ignores them altogether. You can work to get superb SAT scores, and I believe I have given some advice about this in my blog, "Studying in America!” You should learn as much American culture as possible. The Asian education system, both in India and in China, tends to focus on a single subject to the exclusion of all else. The American education system, especially in the Ivy League, tends to value broad and eclectic knowledge: a bit of art, archaeology, history, English, music, psychology, sociology, philosophy – oh, and maybe some science. You should know something about sports. baseball, basketball, and football are the most common, but if you’re applying this year, make sure you know something about such Olympic events as swimming, diving, track and field, and gymnastics. Make sure you keep up with the presidential elections; if you are interviewed, that would be a very common topic for conversation. You might also find it helpful to read some of my posts in Your Academic Evidence. Parke Muth has a blog, and his is much more related to college-level admissions than mine; I specialize in graduate admissions, particularly law school.

Plenty of people have asked similar questions. Plenty of people have answered similar questions. What I would say is simple. Don’t focus so much on GPA. If you have at least a 3.5 it won’t keep you out. What you need to focus on is illustrating to admissions that you have great leadership. You need to start clubs, study groups, businesses, non-profits etc. YOU have to be the leader and founder of these things. It makes sense that Ivy league schools look for these skills. These are skills that are real-world applicable, and really the only skills that matter in determining future success. Some people will get into the Ivy league on intelligence alone, some people will get in on athleticism alone, but most people will get in because they display, in their application, their ability to create successful collaborations that didn’t already exist. You need to be a go getter, a visionary and you need to prove that you can execute on ideas. Unless you’re applying to Cornell, then you just need a 3.2

No. If you give them the right amount of confidence that you've fully recovered, they'll never hold that against you. That would rather benefit you since you've achieved great credentials despite personal hardship. You have to pitch that well in your application. Your credentials sound great and are a lot similar to mine. I'm an Indian. I speak 5 languages, and am developing an app right now. Try talking to your teachers about recommendations ASAP, and what you think should go on them. Don't delay it. Get great recommendations. They're very very important. Anyway. Work on the other parts of your application. Give the SATs. Score above a 1400 out of 1600. Give Atleast 2 subject tests, try scoring above 750 in each of them. Have an external recommender, someone you have professionally worked with( preferably), try doing some paid work. You're pretty much golden.

You get into top schools by having exceptional strength in something. You should be amongst the top couple of hundred seniors in the country at what makes you great, prefferably the top hundred, and you should be able to prove this in your application. Students with that kind of strength generally have the other requirements for admission, and the university will try to admit them as long as they can handle the academic rigour and have no red flags. I recently wrote a post analyzing Harvard admissions. Amongst the population I analyzed, nearly 60% of offers of admission came from the top 4% of applicants. These are mostly students who demonstrated that they belong through one or more great strengths. On average, these students were likely to get in. Yes, more than 18% of admissions came from students in the bottom five sixths of applicants. But on average these applicants were admitted less than 1% of the time. If you want to get in, you need to stand out. The filler that round out classes at elite universities have dreadful a priori odds and are basically counting on luck to get in. You should count on strength.

Your GPA is fantastic. I don't get your PSAT score. Do well on the SATs. I would have advised you to get above a 2200/2400 but the pattern has changed now. So I would advise you to get above a 1450/1600. Your extra-curriculars are good. I would recommend taking( and hopefully acing) olympiads like the physics olympiad. Try to join some physics organization or research facility. Basically anyhands-on contribution like research, external examinations or anything related to that will eventually give you prefrence because it shows your commitment to your field of work. I would definitely recommend applying with Early Decision if you have a specidic college in mind. It literally doubles your chances of being accepted. Not figuratively, literally. I went through some statistics that said that Princeton accepted 18% of their ED students and just 9% of the general pool. Cornell too accepted 38% ED but just 18% general pool. So look into scholarships, your major's program and its rigour and other factors too. Buy the Princeton Review's 378 Best Colleges. I found it to be pretty useful when I was applying.

Do not kid yourself about Ivy league schools. I never went to one and earn far more than anyone i know who did. If its really that important to you do not give up just know you will be in massive debt for 10 yrs and earning ability will not really be anymore than someone from a reasonable school. I went to Cal State Fullerton BSME and Rice University-MBA, my school credentials never made a difference or mattered. In the businesses i now own (four) when i add new people I handle the interview for top execs and new grads the rest i leave to HR and other managers. I am not hiring someone based on what school they went to i am hiring them to grow into the future of the business, will they fit in our business culture. Top two things i want in a new grad (1) business culture are they a good fit (2) do they have good critical thinking quick on their feet skills. My next door neighbor is a plastic surgeon did not graduate from an Ivy league school or even close. He is in a practice with 7 other plastic surgeons all more or less performing the same work, same skills, same specialties, etc. There all paid about the same and two of them did go to Ivy league schools-the bottom line difference? about $400K in student loan debt each have so you tell me.

The college confidential web sight has a forum for each Ivy entry class where the kids post if they got in or not and include a detailed summary of their credentials, fill out a template. The fillled in templates are both depressing and uplifting. There are a huge number of amazing kids applying to the Ivy’s but a lot of them get rejected. Although it is a little misleading - I might apply to 5 Ivy’s get four rejections and still be delighted. A few years back MIT admissions sent the acceptance letters first class and the rejections by carrier pigeon. The kids posted their rejections BEFORE they got them from the pigeon as they knew how long it took first class to get from Mass. to their houses. These are some smart kids.

Whether we like it or not, there is a certain aura that is attached to the Ivy League schools. I have always felt that it is a little overhyped. But my opinion is not important here. It is the collective wisdom of Americans who fall over each other in getting an admit for their children in Ivy League universities. All I say is, that there are lot of schools which are equally good or better than some of the Ivy's. But investment banks or top consulting cos like MBB look at Ivy educated profiles with a much more favourable manner. When they put these candidates before their clients, they expect a certain awe at these profiles. So, these Ivy leagues have the luxury of getting large amount of applications with best possible profiles and have the luxury of selecting a few. . Hence extracurriculars become all the way important. Not list of ECs but excellence in ECs. Ivy leagues are also very expensive. So, excellent academic profile, graduating from reputed private high schools, with near perfect SAT scores and excellence in ECs. As an Indian international student, you may be interested in undergrad or Masters. Just extrapolate the requirements.

I honestly do not think there is any one specific answer. Outstanding grades, positions of leadership, and high end SAT’s won’t hurt. But in reality, what are you doing that makes you stand out or seem special? Have you started a nonprofit? Do you have any patents that you have filed? Are you responsible for any apps? What extreme hardships have you overcome. Are you a legacy? Are you a borderline division 1 athlete? Are you accomplished in the field of music? These are not answers to your questions, but it gives you an idea of what helps other candidates get the nod while others who are equally as gifted do not. I can only wish you the best of luck. It is truly a crapshoot to get in and sometimes it makes no sense while one person gets in and another does not. But whatever you do, give it a shot and apply. Good luck.

Nobody can give you an answer to this question, because there is no answer to this question. There is no formula for getting into an Ivy League university. Each school makes it very clear what their minimum requirements are. But even if you don't meet one of these requirements, something else could outweigh it. Also, you have no idea what other candidates you are going up against. I strongly believe it is not beneficial trying to identify the “things" that will get you a sure acceptance. Such things don't exist.

I don't really know about Ivy League schools ... for the record, MIT is not part of the Ivy League. I have opinions about what MIT wants however: you need to look good on paper (meaning grades, SAT scores, etc.,) -- that's just a given -- plus you need to demonstrate in some way an understanding of what engineering is and a genuine love for engineering. So for demonstrating a genuine interest part of it, you want to have done something, to have built something, and to have done it in some self-directed manner that wasn't part of your formal education, and you want to be passionate about it -- this is hard to fake. I mean it is hard to say exactly what to do, because they don't want you to do things just because it will look good when applying to MIT; they're not interested in a freshman class composed of a bunch of grade-grubbers who have been jumping through academic hoops because their parents tell them to. Also, it has always been my theory that the alumni interview is more important than people give it credit, the alumni interview being a direct means for the Institute to gauge the intangible I-belong-at-MIT quality that I am talking around.

It depends on your academic profile, essays, and letters of recommendation as well. That being said, there is no “winning formula” for acceptance. At the extremely low acceptance rates of Ivy League schools, everybody with a really strong application has a chance, but nothing is set in stone. All you can do now is put your best foot forward when you apply and hope for the best. Each of the Ivy League schools are also different. There's no single type of student who has the best chance for getting into an Ivy League school. Each admissions committee is very careful in how they put together the incoming class and eavh school is unique and different from the others in the Ivy League. Sorry if that's not a satisfying answer. Also, you should know that the Ivy League doesn't have a monopoly in the world of higher education. Acceptance into an Ivy League school does not guarantee success later on. More important than anything is how you use your time in college to grow personally and professionally. For some, an Ivy League school is a good fit, and for others it isn't. It's a very personal decision. Before you decide where to apply, actually visit schools and talk to people to get a feel for what kind of institution you would succeed in. As long as you put in time and effort in the application process, you'll most likely end up at a school that fits you.

A GPA that is 2.7 out of 4.0 is not qualified for the Ivy League. They would not consider a student with that score admissable unless there was some other very unusual circumstance, like you were working 40 hours per week supporting your family. That said, there are many great colleges in the US, some that will accept students with a 2.7 GPA. Don't get caught up in the names and reputations. Start with colleges where your school is within their median 50% ranges, and then tailor your application to fit that college. Good luck.

Probably not. The grades and test scores you give are not high enough. They would expect a 3.8 unweighted and a 2100 on the old SAT (1400 on the new), along with at least the extracurriculars you mention - which should be of documentable national or better yet international level. And they expect you to be taking time to think about the important things in life, to read for your own pleasure and edification. The personal statement is all about demonstrating this.

Do very well in school. Take honor classes and Ace them. Score very high in the SAT. Do extracurricular activities that really interest you not just to pad your application. Make sure you strike a balance between school work and extracurricular time. Don't let it impact your grade. This shows that you are organized, manage your time well and are a good learner as well as self motivated. This should give you plenty to write about in the essay when adcoms want to see a person behind the high GPA and high SAT. Remember they admit people not just stats. There is no guarantee for admission but you stand a good chance of getting admitted to institutions that are comparable that are not ivy schools.

Taking college classes while in high school can be a positive for your application if it shows that you actively sought out courses that interested you and were not available to you at your high school.  However you should never do this to the detriment of your high school gpa.  Your Academic Transcript (rigor + grades) is the single most important piece of information they will be evaluating.  You might be able to make a compelling case because your business took away from your grades.  Or not.  Your grades in your regular classes being 'just OK' is really not OK for highly selective universities.

You need to aim for a SAT score of around at least 2150 on the old scale. The SAT/ACT scores in the Ivy League are getting exceptionally high nowadays. You can do it though.  To be fully honest, I don't see something extremely special in the list of activities. You really need to work on a special EC. I think Olympiads as Pranav suggested is a good idea, but you need to do well. You can't just participate.  Do something special over this upcoming summer. Good luck!

The swiftest way is to be a world-record-holding athlete. This will be the strongest assurance of entry. Legacy helps. I like to say that legacy can heal the sick but it cannot raise the dead. If grades are poor and there are no superb extra curriculars, legacy might not help you. Have high standardized test scores and be a member of a minority or identity group in which the university is interested. As the recent Harvard lawsuit has revealed, Asian applicants are not considered an identity group that needs a boost. To the contrary, they may even face penalties. This makes no sense but biases rarely do. As you can see, some of these point above are things you have control over. Most of them you do not have control over. However, since the common application asks you how you identify your gender, in my opinion one could also identify as a different ethnicity. After all, if you can deny the presence of a Y chromosome why would you not also be able to deny the fact that you are Caucasian or Asian? Perhaps you identify (ethnically and sexually) differently, right? Just my two cents ~

Thanks for the A2A. It is too early to tell what your application profile will look like next year.  There is a lot you can do in the next 10 months to bring up the strength of your application.  Currently your accomplishments are fairly common place but there is still time to improve. Work with a counselor to develop a plan.  There are NO general formulas.  Each student should find their strengths and maximize them and take their weaknesses and improve them. After you develop a comprehensive plan you will be able to evaluate what schools you should apply too.  If all goes according to plan there should be no reason not to have some outstanding schools to apply to Ivy league or not.

What IB subjects have you taken, and what about the SAT? All of your extracurriculars are great… if you meet the academic standards, I see no reason why you shouldn’t be able to get in to an Ivy. By academic standards, you need to have taken a sufficiently high level of math, foreign language, sciences, etc… and you need to do the SAT general, and then depending on what you want to major in, you may need to take a subject test as well.

The way to get into the Ivy League is to ensure that your goal is not the Ivy League. Selective institutions care about who you are and what you bring to the table — not that you slaved over your homework everyday for four years and have a perfect score on everything. They care about your GPA, courseload, and the types of classes you’re taking, and about your extra-curriculars. Who are you as an individual? Colleges don’t want a “well-rounded individual.” They want a “well-lopsided” person who cares deeply about a certain thing. They want that person to contribute something to their community.

Far more is considered than your GPA, so it is pointless to even venture a guess about your chances for admission.  Go to COLLEGEdata: College Search, Financial Aid, College Application, College Scholarship, Student Loan, FAFSA, Common Applicationand enter the name of the school of interest. From the main page, choose Admissions. There you will find data and stats regarding the most recent incoming class at that school.  You can see how you might stack up re: grades and test scores. But keep in mind that your ECAs, letters, essay and interview are all considered as well.  It's not only about academic achievement. It's about who and what you are and what you have to offer.

Move to Wyoming (the smaller the state the greater the chances). Make sure no one else in your school applies (the fewer the better). Get excellent grades and SAT or ACT scores. Impress the hell out of your teachers and get excellent recs. Do something showing leadership and/or (especially and) superior acheivement (Eagle Scout, starting a neighborhood preschool, protesting war in Washington, whatever). Write a great essay. For some Ivies, impress the alumni/ae interviewer you talk to. Be black, one-legged, overcoming some horrible difficulty. Pray.

It's hard to get into ivy league schools, but if you are motivated and ready to study hard you can do it, but on a serious note take many AP classes or higher level classes your school offers and try to maintain a high GPA, try to take many extracurricular activities. I had one person in my school who went to Stanford he took 13 AP subjects and got As in every subject he got perfect fives in ALL of his APs.

You get the attention of the top tier colleges and universities by obtaining excellent scores on your standardized tests like the ACT and SAT. Then to bolster those scores, your high school transcript needs to demonstrate you have taken the most rigorous courses your school offers and progressively gotten better over time. Your actual GPA and class rank are nice indicators, but they are not given a lot of weight. Lastly, you need to write essays on the applications indicating what kind of person you are. They want to know what you do to improve you, your family, and your community outside of school. It is this last part that will make or break your application. They know who the good students are. The first two points are to see if you can handle the academics their schools offer. What they really want to find are good students who will make even better alumni. What are you going to do with the education they are providing? If you spend all your time getting an 1600 SAT, 36 ACT, and 4.0 GPA to be valedictorian, they will not be interested in you. You have not demonstrated your commitment to using your education, only that you know how to learn.

maybe you will maybe you wont; it really doesnt matter; all good undergrad programs are pretty identical; you have to convince them you are special;plenty of kids have high grades; but if you dont get in ; your experience will be just as wonderful; relax it doesnt matter; i have never as an adult been asked where i went to school ever

Assuming you do not have some extraordinary talent - composed a piano concerto at age 5 or set high school track records - to properly answer your question I will need to know your race and identity. A black transgender will have a very different path than a white male. Both will benefit from some demonstrated leadership experience, preferably in some “social justice” field, and a dedicated passion to some skill or field of study - poetry, music, chess, science, etc. While academia is overwhelmingly liberal, if your skills tend toward the entrepreneurial, there is an appreciation for money making ability (expressed in a socially and environmentally favored way), as there is a long term view for future donations. If these concepts sound alien to you, then your college target might be ill-chosen and you should consider other options where you will be equally or even more successful.

Do your homework. Read up on the individual schools and their requirements. If there is a match with what they seek and your credentials, then you have the basic criteria to apply. Note the competition is stiff. It is always advised to apply to non-Ivy League institutions which also offer a great education and are more accessible to “normal” people.

To get into an Ivy League, you need some combination of the following: 1.Stellar recommendations 2. Diverse extracurricular activities 3. Legacy or Double Legacy 4. 96–97 percentile standardized test scores 5. 3.7 gpa or higher or some kind of massive upward trend that culminates into a 3.9+ 6. Athletic draft 7. Some kind of hook

1)you will need a high GPA2)High SAT scores, most of them required a higher score than 2000 (out of 2400) But, don't forget that the SAT is going to change its format so be aware of that3)Recommendations and good extracurricular activities like clubs,sports,etc..4)Depending from where you are coming  from, the tuition could be pretty expensive. But under the assumption you have a good SAT and GPA score, you might be able to find a scholarship. 5)Good essays for the universities' entrance essay questions6)And MOST IMPORTANTLY, A BIT OF LUCK

I have no idea where you are in life: high school, junior college, 4-year degree-offering college, mid-life or wherever. Regardless of your stage, present a coherent story of why you want to go there, what the particular university or college means to you, what you can offer, and how you intend to pay for it. Nothing is guaranteed, of course, but it’s worth the try.

You’re off to the right start. You didn’t mention a GPA, but I’m going to assume that it’s in-line with your other accomplishments. In order to apply to the very top colleges in the US, you need a 3.7 or better GPA, 1450+ on the SATs or 32+ on the ACT, and continue with excellent extracurricular activities. You’ll also need to write excellent college essays. Here’s a post that offers advice on how to write the best essays for Stanford.

I interview regional students for an Ivy, so I have a bit of insight into this. In addition to good grades and excellent character references, the Ivies look for applicants who have shown intense interest in something, pursued it on their own initiative, and succeeded at it. Lots of applicants have a high GPA, good letters, and a laundry list of extracurriculars. But what have they done that’s outstanding, beyond doing what they were told? Doing one thing extremely well is better than a list of activities done to build a resume. It doesn’t matter what it is, the point is that the applicant has the interest and the focus to excel.

I understand that getting into an Ivy League college requires not just good grades, but consistently good grades. The good thing is that everybody can make it. Read this story of an orphaned boy who used to be at the bottom of his class and how he managed to get a full scholarship in Harvard: From an impoverished school in Central Pokot to Harvard: Young entrepreneur tells his story - Kenya Witness

Every Ivy League college is different culturally and also their ways of teaching differs. Apart from your work experience, GPA, test scores, etc the admission officers also evaluate your profile to see if you are the right fit culturally and if you can adjust to the curriculum easily. The cultural fit is often evaluated by your involvement in extracurricular activities and work for a social cause. They also evaluate your passion for the subject that you want to specialize in. This is because the curriculum in Ivy Leagues is majorly based on the practical and experiential learnings and not theoretical. Admissions officers also evaluate your profile to see if you have a clear vision of your short and long-term career goals. Do you have your heart set on a particular career? What have you done to show your liking for that career? These are some of the aspects they look at while evaluating any student profile. Hope this helps. All the best!

A2A. Did you not see the Answer Wiki when you asked this question? As to your question, there is no magic formula to “secure myself into a Ivy League/prestigious college” because applications are subjectively evaluated and compared to the other applicants. What this means is an applicant may be accepted one year and rejected in another with the same qualifications. Each universities website will tell you want they are looking for in an applicant under admissions. You take that information and apply hoping your best is good enough to get in. Botom line: How can I get into an Ivy League college? It starts by learning how to google.

A quick way to know if you are Ivy League material would be to check the class profile page of the schools on your list - not just the GRE/GMAT score, but also their academic / professional achievements - and the backgrounds of some current students. While that would give you a general idea, it won’t give you granular details. So here’s what you can to if you have some more patience. Check out the LinkedIn profiles of the school's alumni, specially their pre-MBA experience. See if you match up to them. Beyond that it’s a matter of putting together a strong application connecting the dots and making it easy for the admissions team to appreciate what you bring to the table. Sameer Kamat

There are many factors to this question. Not having any facts, it’s hard to answer this question. Here’s one way you can get into Harvard. Harvard has an online school. To get into their online program is a simple process. You have to take three courses, you must get an “A” or “B” in these three courses. If you do this, you are automatically admitted into their online program. There’s nothing else to it.

Ivy League colleges usually want students to have a higher GPA. However, the admissions officers know that some high schools give lower grades than others.  Usually if an applicant is in the top 5% of the class, the GPA is ignored. The GPA could be ignored for applicants who score in the top 5% on standardized tests. You also need interesting extracurricular activities and a strong admissions essay. For example, being on student council or doing volunteer work is more interesting than being in the marching band.

Getting accepted to an elite university in the United States will be challenging for you, since by your question you indicate that your knowledge of English — which is required of all students to a high degree of fluency since all lectures and exams are conducted entirely in English — is below average. I suggest you either spend at least a year improving your written, spoken and comprehension skills or if you have the desire and means to attend college in the United States without financial assistance, reduce your expectations to attending a second-level college.
